Manx: Blein hoght cheead jeig. ghaa-yeig as daeed
English: The year eighteen hundred and fifty-two

Manx: Va’n atchim shoh nagh bione dooin lheid ;
English: Occurred such a disaster as we have not known before;

Manx: Nuy deiney as feed dy jeean va stroit,
English: Nine and twenty men were suddenly destroyed,

Manx: Lesh aile as poodyr feer doaltat.
English: By an explosion of powder.[1]
Notes: [1] A closer translation of this line would be; “By fire from powder very suddenly’ (It is likely here that ‘as’ is in fact Nelson’s spelling for ‘ass’.)

Manx: Brig “LILY” v’ee voish Liverpool,
English: The brig “LILY” had come from Liverpool,

Manx: Dys Africa v’ee kiarit goll:
English: And had intended to go to Africa;

Manx: Agh sterrym mooar ren geiyrt ee chionn,
English: But a great storm overtook her.

Manx: Stiagh er yn ellan Kitterland.
English: Driving her in on the island of Kitterland.[2]
Notes: [2] A closer translation of this verse would be; “She was the Brig ‘Lily’ from Liverpool, To Africa she was intended to go, But a big storm drove her fast in onto the island of Kitterland.”

Manx: Ny deiney shoh va loayrit roo
English: These men had been spoken to

Manx: Son dy hauail yn brig as stoo;
English: To save the brig and cargo ;

Manx: Agh roish va traa oc hauail veg,
English: But before they had time to save anything,

Manx: Hie brig as deiney seose jeh’n chreg
English: The brig and men went up off the rock.

Manx: Lane poodyr v’ayn-jee, ta ain baght ;
English: There was much powder on board, we understand;

Manx: Haare aer as aile[3] (shen ren yn cragh)
English: The gas took fire (that made the crash),
Notes: [3] Haare aer as aile] It is likely here that ‘as’ is in fact Nelson’s spelling for ‘ass’ (‘from’) – ‘Gas caught (ignited) from a fire’.

Manx: As trome va’n atchim, chaarjyn deyr,
English: And heavy was the shock, dear friends,

Manx: Tra hrog yn bodjal seose ’syn aer.
English: When the cloud [of smoke] rose up in the air.

Manx: Agh lhig dooin goaill nish baght jeh shoh.
English: And now let us take notice of this.

Manx: Cre’n mirril mooar dy row FER BIO;
English: What a great wonder; there was one man alive

Manx: As ga dy row yn chragh cha dewil.[4]
English: Although the crash was so severe.
Notes: [4] This line is illegible in the original manuscript and is taken from the version printed in the  Isle of Man Examiner, Saturday, February 04 - March 04, 1899; Page: 6.

Manx: V’eh myr banglane sauit as yn aile.
English: He was as a branch saved from the fire.

Manx: As lhisagh eh dagh oie as laa
English: And he should each night and day

Manx: Jeh myghin mooar yn Chiarn imraa ;
English: Speak of the great mercy of the Lord;

Manx: Lesh jeeanid anmey hirveish[5] eh
English: With earnestness of mind serve Him
Notes: [5] There is no obvious reason for lenition of shirveish here.

Manx: Ren sheeyney magh da snaie yn vea.
English: Who lengthened out for him the thread of life.

Manx: Ec Purt Le Moirrey, yn laa shoh chaie,
English: At Port St. Mary the other day,

Manx: (She shoh yn toiggal ta aym veih),
English: (It is from here I got my information),

Manx: Skeerey my ghooie va gennaghtyn,
English: My native parish was feeling,

Manx: Son ny mraane treoghe v’ayn gaccan[6] trome.
English: For the widows that were in such heavy trouble.[7]
Notes:
[6] gaccan] v. 61. moaning, bewailing. (Cregeen)
[7] A closer translation of this line would be; “For the widows there (who were) deeply mourning”.

Manx: Va’n oaie oc seiyt lesh trimshey trome;
English: Their faces were troubled with great sadness;

Manx: Lane cloan gyn ayr va kiongoyrt rhym;
English: Many fatherless children were about me,

Manx: As dys yn cheeill feer dree v’ad troailt.
English: And they were walking very slowly to the church.

Manx: Va’n trimshey oc wheesh cha row ad loayrt.
English: Their sorrow was so great that they were not speaking.

Manx: As ayns yn cheeill feer trimshagh v’ad
English: And in the church they were very mournful

Manx: Ayns coamrey doo ; myrgeddin hood[8]
English: In their mourning clothes. Also to Thee
Notes: [8] The poem is styled as a prayer to God.

Manx: Thousaneyn jeir va shillt dy sharroo,
English: Thousands of tears were bitterly shed,

Manx: Er son ny bioee as ny merriu.
English: Both for the living and for the dead.

Manx: Dooinney dy Yee, yn saggyrt ain,
English: Our parson, a man cf God,

Manx: Ren ad leeideil gys fuill yn Eayn,
English: Led them to the blood of the Lamb,

Manx: Ta clashtyn nish dagh seaghyh trome
English: Who hears now each heavy trouble

Manx: Ben treoghe as cloan gyn ayr ta geam.
English: Of the widow and fatherless children who call (upon Him).

Manx: Lesh boggey ta shin cur diu fys,
English: With joy we let you know

Manx: Ta’n Chiarn ayns chymmey er hroggal seose
English: The Lord in pity has raised up

Manx: Thousaneyn carrey ta. trooid graih,
English: Thousands of friends who, through love.

Manx: Ceau aggle jeu as seaghyn baih.
English: Casting fear away, and drowning sorrow.

Manx: Yn Ellan ain ta trooid graih jeean,
English: Our Island which through earnest love,

Manx: Gaccan as cooaghey myr calmane;
English: Complaining and cooing as a dove ;

Manx: As kuse ta chymsit nish jeh’n cheer
English: And a sum was now gathered from the country[9]
Notes: [9] The phrase ‘ta chymsit nish’ means ‘is now gathered’.

Manx: Dy hroggal seose yn chloan gyn ayr.
English: To bring up the fatherless children.

Manx: Ta deiney seyrey Vannin hene
English: The rich men of our own Isle of Man

Manx: Lesh cree as laueyn ta’d ve jeean[10]
English: With heart and hands were so earnest
Notes: [10] ta’d ve jeean] ‘they are being earnest’. (The 1899 translation places the charitable actions in the past.)

Manx: Ta daa housane as queig cheead punt
English: That two thousand and five hundred pounds

Manx: Chymsit ec deiney runt myrgeart.
English: Were collected in the neighbourhood.

Manx: Ny Sostynee ooasle (t’ad mec jeh stayd),
English: The English nobles are men of state,[11]
Notes: [11] A closer translation of this line would be; “The noble English (they are sons of status)”.

Manx: Lesh spyrryd deiney shen myr t’ad,
English: With men of spirit, such as these,

Manx: Myr Creesteenyn, er hymsagh runt
English: And as Christians, have collected

Manx: Er gerrey da daa housane punt.
English: Nearly two thousand pounds.

Manx: As jerkal t’ain rish queig cheead foast
English: And expecting still five hundred

Manx: Voish naboo Hostyn[12] cour yn chooish:
English: From our English neighbours for the cause.
Notes: [12] naboo Hostyn] — ‘neighbour of England’ this might be a case of non-standard lenition (as seen elsewhere in this piece with ‘hirveish’ used where ‘shirveish’ would be expected) as ‘naboo Sostyn’ – ‘neighbour England’ fits better.

Manx: Ta’n Queen ain ooasle, as neesht reeoil,[13]
English: Our gracious Queen, who still reigns.
Notes: [13] A closer translation of this line would be; “Our queen is noble, and also royal”.

Manx: Ta’n chooish goit eck as daue chymmoil.
English: Took up the cause and had pity for them.

Manx: Yee bannee yn dooinney seyr jeh stayd[14].
English: God bless the rich man of the place.
Notes: [14] jeh stayd] of status.

Manx: Squire Gawne ghow toshiaght lesh e cheead,[15]
English: Squire Gawne began with one (hundred pounds);
Notes: [15] e cheead] his hundred

Manx: E chree lesh chymmey huc ren lheih,
English: His heart was melted with pity for them .

Manx: As Jee nee geeck eh son e ghraih.
English: And God will repay him for his love.

Manx: She shoh yn chraueeaght t’ain ’sy ghoo,
English: This is the faith we have in the Word

Manx: Voish Creest yn Chiarn as Spyrryd Noo;
English: From Christ, the Lord, and Holy Spirit:

Manx: Ynrick as fegooish broid, sheer dooin,
English: Holy and without uncleanness, we are sure,

Manx: Cha nee ayns glare agh obbraghyn.
English: It is not by words but by works.

Manx: She dy gholl huc t’ayns trimshey as feme,
English: It is to go to them in their sorrow and need,

Manx: Rish yn ven treoghe as cloan dy rheynn;
English: To distribute to the widow and the child;

Manx: As liorish graih as casherickys[16]
English: And by love and holiness
Notes: [16] This line is illegible in the original manuscript and is taken from the version printed in the  Isle of Man Examiner, Saturday, February 04 - March 04, 1899; Page: 6.

Manx: Nyn mea y cheau ’sy theihll shoh wass.
English: To spend our[17] lives in this world.
Notes: [17] The translation ‘their’ for ‘nyn would be a better fit here than ‘our’.

Manx: Bee imraa jeant jeh cragh cha dewil
English: Mention will be made of this diesaster so severe

Manx: Ec cloan nagh vel foast bio ’sy theihll,
English: By children who are not yet born,

Manx: Tra vees ny kirp ain ayns yn oaie
English: When our bodies shall be in the grave

Manx: Yn skeeal nee foast gys eashyn roie.
English: The tale will yet to ages run.

Manx: Cha jeean as agglagh shen va’n polt![18]
English: How sharp and frightful was the report—
Notes:
[18] polt] s. m. a blow, stroke, or thump; or perhaps it means the sound or report of a
blow, shot, &c., more than the blow, &c. itself; v. strike, &c.; —AGH, 77; —EE, 80; (Cregeen)

Manx: Nyn girp va raipit er yn spot;
English: Their bodies were torn to pieces on the spot;

Manx: As traa feer ghiare va currit daue,
English: And a very short time was given to them

Manx: Dy chur nyn aghin seose gys niau.
English: To raise their prayers up to heaven.

Manx: As tra vees cayrn Yee er ny hellym:
English: And when the trump of God shall sound :

Manx: “Trog shiu seose, verriu, ass yn joan!”
English: “Rise up ye dead, out of the dust!”

Manx: Ny craueyn shen va brisht as scarrt
English: The bones that were broken and scattered

Manx: Hig reesht dy-cheilley myr v’ad cheayrt.
English: Will come together as they were once.

Manx: Eisht ayns yn laa mooar gloyroil shen
English: Then in that great glorious day

Manx: Nee Chreest gra roosyn vees lesh hene :
English: Christ will say to those who shall be with Him:

Manx: “Immee shiu stiagh dys gerjagh beayn,
English: “Go ye into eternal happiness

Manx: Ghow chymmey jeh mraane treoghe v’ayns feme.
English: For taking pity of the widows in need.

Manx: Son wheesh as ren shiu shoh, nyn currym,
English: For as much as you did this, your duty :

Manx: Da’n vooinjer veg cur coamrey as arran,
English: To the little ones gave clothing and food :

Manx: Ren shiu myrgeddin eh y yannoo dooys,
English: You also did it unto Me,

Manx: As crown dy gloyr yiow shiu lurg baase.”
English: And a crown of glory you shall receive after death.”

Manx: Ta coontey ain ayns Sushtal Chreest,
English: We have an account in the Gospel of Christ

Manx: Jeh toor Siloam, dty[19] huitt eh sheese.
English: Of the tower of Siloam, which fell down,
Notes: [19] dty] evidently a misprint for ‘dy’.

Manx: As faggys da va kuse ayns earroo,
English: And nearly the amount in number.

Manx: Hoght deiney jeig, goit fo as marroo.[20]
English: Eighteen men, taken under and killed.
Notes: [20] marroo] dead

Manx: Ta Yeesey gra rooin ayns yn goo
English: And Jesus tells us in the Word

Manx: Nagh row ad shoh ny peccee smoo,
English: That these were not greater sinners;

Manx: Agh, fegooish arrys cooie, dy jean
English: But without meet and earnest repentance

Manx: Ny bioee ooilley cherraghtyn.
English: The living would all suddenly perish.[21]
Notes: [21] Agh, fegooish arrys cooie, Dy jean ny bioee ooilley cherraghtyn.] The 1899 translator appears to have misread ‘dy jean’ as ‘dy jeean’. A closer translation of these two lines would be; “But, without proper repentence, All the living will perish’.

Manx: Lhig diuish as dooys, ta bio er-mayrn,
English: Let you and me, who are still alive,

Manx: Lesh jeeanid cree hirveish yn Chiarn ;
English: With earnestness of heart serve the Lord,

Manx: Dy vod mayd cosney foayr as grayse,
English: That we may gain favour and grace,

Manx: As maynrys niau tra yiow mayd baase.
English: And the happiness of heaven when we shall die.

Manx: Amen.
